STREETDIRECTORY.REVISEDDECEMBER,1886.(SeealsoHalleandBalldings;alsoListofParks.)Thestreetsnamedbythelettersoíthealphabetaridnumerals,respectively,arelaidoutatrightangles,theformerrunningcastandwestfromNorthandSouthCapitolStreets,andthelatterrunningnorthandsouthfromEastCapitolStreetandtheMall,streetssonamedbeingnotincludedinthefollowinglist.TheavenuesnamedforStatesoftheUnionrundiagonallyfromdifferentcenters,themostprominentbeingtheCapitolandtheExecutiveMansion*.Manyoftheoriginalblocksorsquaresweresolarguethatnewstreetsandalleyshavebeenopenedandnamed,thelistofwhichshowsacontinuedincreasefromyeartoyear.Thedecimalsystemofnumberingisused;itisontheprincipleofallowingonehundrednumberstoeachsquare,andgreatlyfacilitatesfindingaparticularnumber,andisadvantageousineaseofаИгеorthetearingdownofablockofbuildings,thenumbersthatfollownotbeingtherebydisarranged.Alladdresseshavetheadditionaldesignationofnorthwest,southwest,northeastorsoutheast,accordingtotheirdirectionfromtheCapitol,uponthemeridianofwhichMajorL'Enfantconstructedtheplanofthecity;theCapitolbuildingisverynearlytheexactcenterofthecity.Ard,frPiney-branchrdAckeralnw,seeChewalnwAcornalaw,seeAikenalswAdamsExpressalnw,seeExpressalnwAdams-millrd,frColumbiaidAdamsstAnacostia,frHarrisonAikenalsw,fr2094\ito4в5СAingerav,frHamiltonrdtoBruceavAlexanderalnw,fr2033Кto2034LAlexanderrownw,fr1136to1142NIIavAllenctsw,fr3dto4)4betLandMAmanctnw,fr906DAnscostia,apostvillageonthesouthbankoftheAnacostiariver,oppositetheNavyYardAnacostiaheights,betNicholsavandGoodHoperd,seofAnacostiaAnacostiard,frAnacostiatoBenningsAqueductstGtn,nowPaavnwArgj'Ie-mtllrd,seeBlagdenrdArmorystnw.seeJacksou-hallalnwArmorystsw,fr1114Цto1566thArthurpinw,betВandC,NJavand1stВrd,frPinev-branclirdBackstnw,frVab35thBaconalaw,fr464Eto465FBaconstnw,fromPiney-branchrdbelColumbiardBaileyalse,frlUbbelNBaileyalsw,betHalfand1st,NandОBaldwinrownw,seeUnionalnwBallalnw,fr7122dand227Gto222MassатBankrtnw,fr3329Mto3332ProspectavBaptistaluw,fr920FBaptist-churchaluw.fr72313thBarralnw,fr4 YoungMenandWomenshouldfirstobtainacommon-schooleducation;thenapracticalbusinesseducation.Thisisthewisestcourse;for,whatevertheirsubsequenteducationalopportunitiesmaybe,theirbusinesstrainingwillatanytimesecureforthemworthypositionswheretheycansupportthemselvesandthosewhomaybedependentuponthem,andsuccessfullyperformtheactivedutiesofreallife.CornerNinthandDStreets,N.W.,-^WASHINGTON,D.Z.^.AThorough,PracticalCourseofInstructionandTraining.AFullCorpsofTeachers.DayandEveningSessions.TheNationalCapitaloffersyoungmenandwomensuperioradvantagesforbusinesseducationatSpencerianBusinessCollegewhichhassentforthover600graduatestofillpositionsofhonor,trust,andprofitduringthepasttwentyyears.Afewmonthsatthenationalcapital,(itselfavastuniversity,)devotedtomas-!teringacourseofbusinessinstructionandtraining;isasuperlativeeducationalopportunityfortheyouthofourcountry.ThecosttothosewhoarepreparedtoentertheSpecialBusinessCourseisIwithinthereachofpersonsofonlymoderatemeans.HowEducationalAdvantagesareimproved.WhocanentertheBusinessCollege.Recordsshowthatonlyaboutone-halfofonepercent,ofallpupilsincitypublicschoolscompletetheHighSchoolcourse,andthatlessthanfourper•cent,entertheeighthgrade.Thenecessitiesoflifebearhardlyonfamilies,andsonsanddaughtersaretakenfromschoolearlyandputtoearningalivelihood.ApplicationsarecontinuallybeingmadeattheofficeoftheBusinessCollegeItoreceivestudentswhoaretooyoungandundisciplinedtotakeupaBusinessCourse.Youngmenandyoungwomenwhohavethoroughlycompletedtheseventhor■eighthgradeofpublicschools,oracorrespondingcourseinotherschools,oramoreadvancedcourse(providingthefoundationwaswelllaid)canentertheBusinessCollege,andbyattendingdaysessionscompletetheBusinessCourseiinoneyear.TheNaturalHeadofthePublicSchools.Thevenerábleeducatorandpracticalbusinessman,Prof.J.B.Turner,ofIllinois,says:"TheBusinessCollegehascomeouttodaythenaturalheadand■properleaderofthecommonschoolsofallthisgreatrepublicofoverfiftymillionsofpeople.:*At*Ithasthoroughlydugdowntotheveryfoundationrocktruthsofpracticaleducation;hasneatlyandcleverlycastasidealltheiTtibbishwithwhichtheywereoverloaded.***Itteachespracticallywhat¡thesefifty,millionsofpeopleneedtoknow."









SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.5BusinessTrainingaSpecialty.Thecommercialdepartmentofaliteraryorscientificschoolisanefforttomeetademandofthepeople;butitconstantlylaborsunderthedisadvantageofbeinghamperedbyasystemofarrangementsandregulationsadaptedtotheotherdepartments,butnotadaptedtobusinesstraining.Theliteraryandscientificdepartmentsareratedhigherthanthecommercialdepartment,andstudentsinthelatterfeeltheeffectsinmanydirections.Ayoungmaninsuchadepartmentofalargeinstitutionsaidtohisparents:"IbelievethatIhavechosenrightlyinpreparingforausefulbusinesscareer,butIamcontinuallyremindedthatthestudentspursuingtheclassicalandscientificcoursesdonotregardourclassastheirequals.Iprefertoattendaninstitutionwheremyaimsandambitionsareappreciatedandtreatedwithduerespect."TheBusinessCollegemakesbusinesstrainingitsspecialwork.Allofitsfacilitiesandappliancesandregulationsarebasedonthatidea,anditsstudentsarerankedupontheirpracticalability,trustworthiness,andgeneralbusinessqualifications.ScholasticYear.Scholarshipsforascholasticyearoftenmonthsareissuedatanytime.Theyearlyarrangementis,financiallyandintellectually,themostadvantageoustothestudent.Arrangementscanalsobemadebythequarteratconvenienceofapplicants.Graduation.—Itisfortheinterestofthosewhoenteruponacourseofbusinesstrainingthattheyshouldcompleteit,andgraduatewithhonor.Therebytheysecurethoroughknowledgeandskill,andpassingoutintothebusinessworldwiththeendorsementoftheInstitution,obtainsituationsmoreeasilyandmaintainthemmoresuccessfully.DaySessions.HoursofInstruction,9A.M.to2.30P.M.onMondays,Tuesdays,Wednesdays,Thursdays,andFridays.RequisitesforAdmissiontoBusinessCourse.Personsofgoodcharacter,overfifteenyearsofage,whounderstandArithmeticthroughpercentage,andhaveafairknowledgeofEnglishgrammar,willbereceivedintheSeniorDepartment.ApplicantsforadmissiontothisCollegeundertwenty-oneyearsofagearerequestedtobringwiththemlettersfromtheirlastteacherscertifyingtotheirgoodcharacter.Applicantsovertwenty-oneyearsofagearerequestedtobringnotesofintroduction,ortogivesuitablereference.TheBusinessCourse.TheBusinessCourseembracestheEnglishLanguage,BusinessArithmetic,SpencerianPracticalPenmanship,Bookkeepingbysingleanddoubleentry,adaptedtoeveryvarietyofbusiness;BusinessPractice,requiringthemakingoutandexchangingofallkindsofbusinesspapers,payingandreceivingcash,keepingtheaccountsandwritingletters;VocalandPhysicalTraining;LecturesonPoliticalEconomy;CommercialGeography;CommercialLaw;andBusinessEthics.SuccessfulBusinessMen,Lawyers,Physicians,ScientificMen,andStatesmenfromtimetotimeaddressthestudentsuponsubjectsrelatingtotheirvariouscallings.TimeRequired.—StudentspreparedbytheirknowledgeofthecommonEnglishbranchestoenterupontheBusinessCoursemaycompleteitinfromsixtotenmonths.Diploma.—TheDiplomaoftheCollegeisawardedtothosewhocompletetheprescribedcourseandpassasatisfactoryexamination.Diplomafee,$5-00.TuitionFeesforDaySessions.FortheBusinessCourse.BytheQuarter,(10weeks,)payableonadmission....$20.00BytheYear(ascholarshipfortenmonths).....$70.00The$70ispayable,$10onadmissionandremainderinmonthlyinstalmentsof$10each.BytheYear,cashinfullonentering,$60.00ThisistheleastexpensivearrangementforenteringthisCollege,andtheScholarshipisgoodfortea•months,dayoreveningsessions.Norm—Studentsenteringforayearontheinstalmentplan,andnotcompletingthecontract,arechargedattherateof$10permonthwhileinattendance.CostofBooksandStationery.—BooksandstationeryfortheBusinessCourse,costaboutSioonenteringand$5moreduringthecourse.■Thearticlesforthestudent'soutfitmaybepurchasedattheCollege.SicknessandRemovals.IfastudentispreventedbyprotractedsicknessfromattendingtheCollegeduringatermforwhichhistuitionhasbeenpaid,hemay,uponapplicationtothePrincipal,obtainanextensionoftimeofattendance.Ifcircumstancesbeyondhiscontrolcompelastudent'sremovalfromthecityoritsvicinity,hemay,uponpresentingsatisfactoryevidenceofthefact,beaccordedtheprivilegeofallowingsomepersonacceptabletothePrincipaltoattendinhisplaceduringanunexpiredterm.

SPENCÊRIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.7FeaturesoftheBusinessCourse.Bookkeeping.—InitiatoryCourse.InthissectionthetruescientificprinciplesofBookkeepingareunfolded;thelawsofdebitandcreditasappliedtothevariousclassesandvarietiesofaccountsarefullyillustrated,andthepracticalformsofnotes,orders,drafts,checks,receipts,andotherbusinesspapersincommonuse,areclearlytaughtaccordingtotheusageofthebestsystematizedbusinesshouses.SeveralvarietiesofordinarybusinessarerecordedinDay-Book,Journal,andLedger,andtheJournalDay-Bookisintroduced.IntermediateCourse.Inthissection,shipmentsandconsignmentsareintroduced,accountsalesarerendered,balancesheetsmadeout,theCashBookandSalesBookareintroduced,asprincipalbooks;theBillBookandCheckBookasauxiliaries.Businessoflargerextentisundertakenwithagreatervarietyoftransactions.AdvancedCourse.Inthissection,thestudentopensbusinesswithsingleentrybooks,changestodoubleentry,learnstheuseoftheSpecialColumnJournal,keepsandlearnstheuseofaPettyLedger,postingitatintervalstoMainLedger,keepscompletepracticalsetsofbooksrespectivelyinwholesale,retail,andcommissionhouses,andinanationalbank.PracticalPenmanship.—Thestudentspursuingthebusinesscoursearetrainedandrequiredtowriteaplain,neat,legibleandrapidhand.ThepenmanshiptaughtisbasedupontheSpencerianideaofsecuringthehighestrateofspeedconsistentwithgoodform.Thoroughinstructioninthisartiscontinuedthroughoutthecourse,andstudentsattainahighstandardofexcellenceinwriting.Thename"Spencerian"hasbecomesynonomouswithgoodwritingtheworldover.Vocaland.PhysicalTraining.—AmongthedelightfulmemoriesstudentscherishconcerningCollegeexperiences,arethedaily,morningexercisesinvocalandphysicaltraining,andtheFridaymorningliteraryandmusicalentertainmentsinwhichallareallowedtoparticipate.Thetraininginbreathing,movements,poise,andcarriageofthebody,developmentofthevoice,andcultivationoftheliterarytaste,resultsinageneralimprovementinstyleandmanners,aneaseandgraceandfluencyofspeechwhichwinthewarmestcommendationsoffriendsandresultinincalculablebusinessandsocialadvantages.Lectures:CommercialLaw,BusinessEthics,PoliticalEconomy,CommercialGeography,Health,CitizenshipandtheScienceofGovernment,arepresentedtothestudentsincomprehensiveandsuggestivelecturesfromwhichtheytakenotes.BusinessArithmetic.—BusinessArithmeticisoneoftheessentialbranchesofabusinesscourse.YoungmenandwomenwhohavestudiedtheordinaryarithmeticsandarithmeticalmethodsintheschoolstheyhaveattendedfindintheSpencerianCollegeamuchmorepractical,thorough,andcomprehensivecourseoftrainingincalculations,acourseinwhichcloseattentionisgiventotheshort,rapidmethodswhichareadaptedtobusinessandareemployedinbusiness.ClassesofdifferentgradesareestablishedintheCollege,sothatstudentsenteringatdifferenttimesmaybeplacedaccordingtotheirattainments.ActualBusinessPractice.—ThestudentafterpassingthroughthestagesofhiscoursepreparatorytoActualBusinessPractice,locatesandestablisheshimselfinbusinessintheCollege.Heinvestscapital,makespurchasesforcashandontime,depositsintheCollegebank,givesandreceivesnotes,checks,drafts,receipts,duebills,orders,&c,writesandreceivesbusinessletters,paysrents,insurance,andtaxes,keepshisbooksbydoubleentry,inaccordancewiththemethodsemployedbytheleadingbusinesshousesofourcountry.Asmerchantandbanker,thestudentlearnspracticallythelawsofsupplyanddemandaffectingprices,thecustomsofbusinesstowhichhemustconform,thelawsofcontractsandtheobligationsofparties,thelawsofcopartnershipsandcommercialpapers,therelationsofprincipalandagent,&c,&c.TheEnglishLanguage.—Thepower,range,flexibility,harmony,andbeautyoftheEnglishlanguageareunfoldedtothestudentoftheSpencerianBusinessCollegedayafterday,untilitbecomessecondnatureforhimtoexpresshimselfingracefulandappropriatelanguage.TheLanguageLessonsarebaseduponatext-bookpublishedespeciallyfortheSpencerianBusinessCollegebyMrs.SaraA.Spencer,theVice-Principal,whoconductsthedepartmentoftheEnglishLanguageinthisInstitution.Thelittlebookiscalled"ThirtyLessonsintheEnglishLanguage."ForinformationinregardtotheSpencerianBusinessCollegeorforcircularscallattheCollegeoffice,cornerNinthandDStreets,northwest,Washington,D.C,oraddress—Principal.Mrs.SaraA.Spencer,Vice-Principal.




SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.TheWorkorth.RtiRiiie»»College.Instructioninthebus-nesscollegehasadirectbearinguponselfhelpandpersonalindependence.Itrelatestoearningmoney,toitsuseandabuse.Itisscarcelypossibleforayoungftгsontoreachtherationaltageoflife,withoutobtablingsomeideaofthepowersecuredbymoney.Howimportantthatthetrueideashouldbeinculcated.Themerepos-sessionofmoneyshouldnotbeinitselfanend.butonlyameanstoim-Mtmntends.Theseendsigeneral,areexpressedbytheworduse.TheAmericanbaynesscollegeistheeducationalexponentofthispracticalage.Thepeopleofourcountryhaveriversitamightyimpulseforward,becauseofitsutilitarianmission,Ithasbeendemonstratedthatthepracticalandusefulinbusinesscoursesofstudyservetoarousetheyouthfulambition,disciplinethementaltndmoralfaculties,anddevelopefficient,enterprising,reliablecitizenship.—FromPrindp¿HenryC.Spenter¡addressbeforetheBusinessEducators'ConventionatJacksonville,M,Julyo,/SSs-




SPEXCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.УSpecialBusinessCourse.PersonswhohavebeensothoroughlytrainedintheEnglishLanguageandArithmeticasnottoneedfurtherinstructioninthosebranches,canenterforthe"SpecialBusinessCourse,"embracing:Bookkeeping,practicalmethods,bysingleanddoubleentry,appliedtothevariouskindsofbusiness.Athoroughandcompletecourseincludedinthreesections,viz.:—Initiatory,Intermediate,andAdvanced.BusinessPractice,interesting,comprehensive,andefficient,representingbusinessasitisactuallytransactedinthebusinessworld,involvingmethodsofdoingbusiness,fullsetsofbooks,necessaryletters,telegrams,contracts,deeds,bonds,advertising,andallusefulformsofbusinesspapers;receivingandpayingcash,keepingaccountsatbank,etc.,etc.BusinessCorrespondence.Fullinstructioninregardtoletter-writing,abundantpracticeunderdirectionofinstructors,student'sletterscriticizedandcorrecteduntilproficiencyisattained.Lectures,onBusinessEthics,PoliticalEconomy,CommercialLaw,etc.ThisCoursecanbecompletedinfromsixteentotwentyweeks,attendingdaysessions,anddevotingatleasttwohourseacheveningtohomestudy.ApplicantsfortheSpecialBusinessCoursearetestedastotheirfitnesstoenteritbypracticalquestionsandwork,intheEnglishLanguageandArithmetic.Tuition,$40forcourse,notexceedingatermoftwentyweeks.Tuitionforanyadditionaltime,atthesamerate.Costofbooksandstationeryabout$5onenteringand§5moreduringthecourse.TheCollegediplomaawardedtothosewhocompletethecourseandpassasatisfactoryexamination.Diplomafee,$5.Board.Board,includingroom,etc.,infamiliesforstudentsfromabroad,maybeobtainedforÍ20to$25permonth,uponapplicationattheCollege.NocityandnoinstitutionintheUnitedStatescanofferbetterinducements.EVENINGSESSIONS.TheBusinessCoursecanbecompletedbyattendingeveningsessions,andtheCollegeDiplomasecureduponpassingthefinalexamination.Morethan200studentsofthenightclassesofthisinstitutionhavecompletedthebusinesscourseandgraduatedwithinthepasttwenty-oneyears,ForWhomDesigned.—Theeveningsessions,whichareentirelydistinctfromthedaysessions,aredesignedfortheinstructionofmen,women,andyouth,withoutregardtoage,whoareengagedduringthedayinofficesandinvariouskindsofbusiness,butwishtosecureapracticaleducationthatwillenablethemtoobtainbetterpositionsandhigherpay.Ayoungmanwhodevoteshimselfearnestly-tothebusinesscourseatnightsessions,givinghisalternateeveningstostudy,andapplyingtohiscollegeworkthepracticalideasgainedbyhisdailybusinessexperience,makessuchrapidprogressinthecourseastosurprisehimselfandwintheheartyapprovalofhisfriendsandemployers.Itisanobviousfactthathundredsandthousandsofyoungpeoplewhogreatlyneedbusinesstrainingwastetheirevenings,theirearnings,andtheirenergiesintheconstantpursuitofamusement,therebysacrificingeventheircapacityforhappiness,sinceamusementcontinuallypursuedceasestoamuse.TheeveningcourseattheBusinessCollegeisrenderedattractivetothestudentbythefriendlyinterestinhispermanentwelfareshownbyhisteachersandbyhisownconsciousnessthatheisimprovinghismental,financialandsocialcondition.Theexercisesareconductedinsuchamannerthatnoembarassnientisexperiencedbyanystudentwhoisearnestlyendeavoringtoimproveopportunities.EveningsandHours:—ThesessionsareheldonMonday,Wednesday,andFridayeveningsofeachweek.TheHoursofInstructionarefrom6to8.30o'clockP.M.TuitionFeesforEveningSessions.OneYear,tobepaidinfullonadmission......S50.00ThreeMonths,payable$6onenter-•cat•ingandbalanceinmonthlyinstalmentsof$6each-..18.OOThreeMonths,cashonentering16.00Thetuitionfeepaidentitlesthestudenttoinstructioninallbranchesoftheeveningcourse,orinsuchofthebranchesashemayselectwiththeadviceofhisteachers.CostofBooksandStationery,fortheEveningSeniorCourse,isfrom$6to$8;forEveningSub-SeniorCourse,about$5.TheycanbeobtainedintheCollegeoffice.TheEveningCoursekmhraces:Spen-cerianpracticalPenmanship,Bookkeeping,bysingleanddoubleentry,adaptedtoeveryvarietyofbusiness;BusinessPractice,requiringthemakingoutandexchangingofallkindsofbusinesspapers,payingandreceivingcash,keepingtheaccountsandwritingtheletters;BusinessArithmetic,Spelling,Lectures,andtheEnglishLanguage.




IOSPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.DEPARTMENTOFSTENOGRAPHYANDTYPEWRITING.THESTENOGRAPH.SpecialMerits.Itcanbelearnedinone-thirdthetimethepencilsystemsrequire.Itsuseispleasantanddoesnotstraintheeyes,handsorbody.Allitsworkisuniformandmechanicallyexact.Itcanbeoperatedinthedarkaswellasinthelight.Thewritingofoneoperatorcaneasilybereadbyanother.ByItsuse,penparalysisisnotpossible.Itcanbeusedwithoutlookingatit,leavingtheeyesfreetofollowthespeaker'semotions.WehaveintheStenograph,asystemofshorthandasrapidasanyother,themostexactanduniform,theleastIIinpractice,andbyfarthemosteasilyandquicklylearned.Weight,ч#lbsPortable,noiselessandsimple.TheOldWay.—WithPencil.Yearsofstudyandpractice;terriblementalstrain.Illegibleandunreliable.TESTIMONIALS.TheamanuensiswhodoesalargeportionofmywritingusestheStenograph.TheStenographis,beyondquestion,asuccess.BENJ.BUTTERWORTH,M.C,HouseofRepresentatives.AnyyoungpersonpossessingagoodEnglisheducation;whocanwriteontheStenographгпжdictationatarateof100to15cwordsperminute,andcanmakeneat,accuratetranscriptionsontheType-Writerwithrapidity,cancommandagoodsalaryand_steadyemployment.Ladiesandgentlemenwhohavebeentrainedinthisdeparmtenttthisinstitution,arenowoccupyinglucrativeposition?inthisandothercities.TheNewWay.—WithStenograph.Quicklylearned,nostrainofeyes,handsorbody.Workuniformandaccurate.IconsidertheStenographfarbeyondanysystemofpenorpencilshorthand.Inamonth'*,timeIcouldwritefromdictationasrapidlyaswhenIhadbeenstudyingthePitmansystemforayear.TheStenographwasthemeansofsecuringmelucrativeemployment.MARYA.SALTMER.StoddartPublishingCompany,623and624Fst.,n.w.,city.IfindtheStenographforofficeuseanddictationmuchmoresatisfactorythanthepenorpencilworkofanyofthenumerousstenographerswhomIhaveemployedinmyseveralyears'experiencehere.OSCARP.AUSTIN.NewspaperCorrespondent,northeastcornerPenn.ave.and14thst.,city.WehavehadaStenographinuseinourofficeforthepastsixmonths,andconsideritfarbetterthantheordinarystyleerphonographicwork.JM.STODDART&CO.,PacificBuilding,622Fstreet,city.IpurchasedaStenographformydaughteraboutthemiddleof.March.1885,attheSpencerianBusinessCollegeinthiscity.Shetookathreemonths'courseoflessonsthereonatsaidcollege,andpracticed,onanaverage,onehoureachdayforeightmonths,attheendofwhichtimeshewasenabledtosecureprofitableemployment.Shecannowwrite120wordsperminute,currentwork.andreadshernoteswithease.IamdelightedwiththeStenograph,andbelieveittobeofgreatpracticalutility:andasitcanbelearnedmorereadilythananypencilsystemof"Shorthand,"itissuretoworkitswayintopublicfavor.W.H.CROWELL.6thAuditor's.Office,IJ.S.TreavDept




SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.нDEPARTMENTOFSTENOGRAPHYANDTYPE-WRITING.TYPE-WRITING.Probablynootherinventionofmoderntimeshasdonesomuchtoeconomizetime,reduceexpensesandfacilitatethedispatchofofficebusiness,andtolightenthelaborsofoverworkedliteraryandprofessionalmen,astheType-writer.Itsavesmuchphysicallabor,mentalexertionandvaluabletime.Itiseasilylearnedandcanbeoperatedatgreatspeedwithbutlittlefatigue.Astheoperatorofthemachinecansitinanydesiredposition,andwritewithanyfingerofeitherhand,itismanifestthatthedrudgeryofwritingwiththepen,wherebyonlyacertainsetofmusclesisusedandastrainedpositionofthebodynecessitated,isavoidedentirely.TheTypewritersavestheeyesandquickensthebrain.Theaveragespeedofthepenisfromfifteentotwentyfivewordsperminute.TheaveragespeedoftheTypewriterisfromfortytoeightywordsperminute.ProfessionalmenfindgreatreliefintheuseoftheType-writerfromthedrudgeryofpenwriting.LegalpapersarenowverygenerallypreparedwiththeType-writer,whoseplainandelegantprintissaidtobemorelegiblethanthepenmanshipofsomelawyers.SermonspreparedupontheType-writercanbeeasilyread,eveninapoorlight.ClergymanareenthusiasticinpraiseoftheTypewriter.StenographersfindtheType-writeralmostindispensableintranscribingtheirnotes.CharlesReade,inhisworkon"TheComingMan,"says:"Iadviseparentstohavealltheirboysandgirlstaughtstenographyandtype-writing.AstenographerwhocantypewritehisnoteswouldbesaferfrompovertythanagreatGreekscholar.ThousandsofrefinedandcultivatedyoungladiesandgentlemenalreadyfindpleasantandprofitableemploymentintheuseoftheType-writer;andstillthedemandforexpertoperatorsexceedsthesupply.EmploymentforLadies.NoprofessionaffordsabetteropeningforyoungladieswhodesiretoearntheirownlivingthanStenographyandTypewriting,andweknowofno-moreagreeableandprofitableemploymentinwhichtheycan.beengaged.Theiradaptibilitytotheworkhasbeenthoroughlytestedandtheyhavebeenfoundfullyequal,ifnotinmanyinstancessuperior,toyoungmen,asStenographandType-writeroperators.Theyseemtohaveanaffinityforthelittlemachines,judgingfromthereadinesswithwhichtheymasterthem.TuitionFees.(Includinginstruction,useofmachines,stationery,etc.)StenographyandType-writing,permonth....-StenographyandType-writing,threemonths(Fullcourse)Stenography,permonth"threemonths-Type-writing,permonth,"3months,$S.oo20.005.0012.005.0012.00"Specialdiscountof20percent,whentakeninconnectionwiththebusinesscourseoftheCollege.HoursofInstruction.MorningSessions,from9to12everyweekday.AfternoonSessions,fromIto4everyweekday.EveningSessions,from6to8.30everyweekday.ForfurtherinformationapplyatCollegeoffice.HenryC.Spencer,Principal.SaraA.Spencer,Vice-Principal.LeonardG.Spencer,TeacherofStenographyandTypewriting.









SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.'3FromtheDailyNationalRepublicantMay7,jS86.READYFORBUSINESS.TheCommencementoftheSpencerianBusinessCollege.SeventyYoungI.iulyandGentlemenSlMmtH-AnAudienceоГ.Ч.ОООPeoplePreaeul—TheAdflrewnenofGraduate*andProf.andMrs.Spencer—SenatorYoorheen(livesGoodAdvice.Thedull,leadencloudswhichdividedthefourteenhoursofdaylightyesterdaywiththesunimpelledmostofthe3,000peoplewhowentintoAlbaugh'sat3o'clockintheafternoontotakeumbrellas.Onceinside,whereeverybodyoneknewintownwashurryingthroughthebigdoors,afanwasfarmerenecessarythanaparachute,andafterthepeopleweresettledintheirseatsandhadreadthenamesoftheseventyyoungladiesandgentlemenwhocomposedthegraduatingclassoftheSpencerianBusinessCollege,thefanscameintogeneraluse.Therewasnotavacantseatinthetheatreandpeoplewhocamelatehadtostandupintheaisles.Thewidespaciousstagewasbankedupatthefrontwithonegreatbedofflowers.JustinfrontofthiswasDirectorJohnSousaandtheU.S.MarineBandandoccupyingseatsuponthestagewerePrincipalHenryC.Spencer,Vice-PrincipalMrs.SaraA.Spencer,Prof.andMrs.LeonardGarfieldSpencer,Mr.TodRoy,Dr.MontagueR.Leverson,Prof.GeorgeE.Little,PresidentandMrs.W.H.Sadler,ofSadler,Bryant&Stratum,BusinessCollege,Baltimore;PresidentT.J.Pnckett,ofCollegeofCommerce,Philadelphia;Mrs.D.P.Kinney,ofSpencerianBusinessCollege,Milwaukee,Wis.;SenatorDanielW.Voorhees,JudgeD.K.Canter,Hon.M.G.Emery,PrincipalE.A.Paul,Hon.J.OrmondWilson,Mr.A.S.Pratt,Rev.JabezFox,theseventysweetgirlandhandsomeyoungmengraduates.Justbefore3o'clocktheMarineBandrenderedthreeecharmingselectionswhichwereloudlyapplauded,andthenRev.JabezFoxdeliveredtheinvocation.AMexicanserenadebytheorchestragavetheaudiencetimetoregardthegraduates,andthelatteranopportunityofthinkingaboutwhattheyweregoingtosay.TheGentlemen'sSai.itatorywasdeliveredbyII.NormanFleming,oftheU.S.PensionOffice,amemberofthenightclass.Hesaid:FriendsoftheClassof'86:—Atthebeginningofthiseventfulyear,whenweenteredtheSpencerianCollegeHalls,wewerebidden,everyone,toclearlystatewhatwebelievedourintellectualdeficienciestobe,whatweproposedtodotorepairthem,whatwereourplansinlife,andwhatweintendedtodoforourselves,forthosedependentuponus,andfortheworldarounduswhenwehadacquiredourbusinesstraining.Whatafieldofinquiry!Theresponsibilitiesoflifeandtheopportunitiesanddutiesoftheyearbeforeuslaylikeanopenbookunderoureyes.Monthbymonthastheyearhasgonebyhavethesequestioningsinvariousformsbeenrepeated,andhigheratmshavebeenpresented,worthierambitionsaroused,newpowersawakened.ThestudentsofthenightclassesoftheBusinessCollegearenotthepettedsonsofwealthandleisure.Theyworkalldayandstudyatnightthatnextday'sworkmaybebetterdone.And,oh!howgladandgratefulwearefortheprivilege!Whatwouldourfathershavegivenforsuchhelpfulandhopefulchancesinlife?Whatcostthemyearsofstruggleandsadexperiencetoobtain,isoursforthestretchingoutofourhands,forafewstepsofourwillingfeet,forabuoyanteffortofayouthfulbrain.Not"slowandsure,"but'quickandsure"isthedeviceadoptedbyourcollege.Theswiftpen,thereadyhand,theactivebrain,arewantedoutintheworldwhereweareworking.Woe!tothelucklesswightwhoattemptstostemthetideofcivilservicereformwiththewornoutbannerofaneffetecivilization,thevicarious"influence"ofapoliticallogroller.Theinfluencewewantisthesilenttestimonyofworkwelldone,thesoulcheeringconsciousnessofyourapprovalandtrust.Kindfriends,thewordswithwhichwewouldexpresstoyouthetruewelcomeinourheartsto-dayhavebeenspokensooftenbyothers,that,perchance,theymayhavesomewhatlosttheirmeaning,butastheeverdear"Iloveyou"soundsjustastrueandsweetto-dayasitdidinParadise,soletushopeyouwillbelieveusnowasweextendtoyouourearnestWelcome!Welcome!Welcome!ThiswasfollowedbyacornetsolobyMr.W.F.Smith.TheLadies'Sai.itatorywasdeliveredbyMissBerthaL.DeGraffe,ofthedayclass,daughterofthedistinguishededucator,thelateProf.EsmondV.DeGraffe."Thereisnothingcanequalthetenderhours,Whenlifeisfirstinbloom;Whentheheartlikeabeeinawildofflowers,Findseverywhereperfume;Whenthepresentisall,anditquestionsnotIfthoseflowersshallpassaway;Butpleasedwithitsowndelightfullot,Dreamsneverofdecay."friends,youareheretowelcomeustothebusypathsyouhavebeentreadingformanyyears,andweareheretowelcomeyoutoabriefparticipationinthebrightvisionsofyouth.Youperchancearethinking:"I,too,sleptanddreamedthatlifewasbeauty,Iwokeandfoundthatlifewasduty."Youarewonderingwhatweshalldollitho.e




'4SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.knowledgewehavebeengaining.Youtellusthatthetimes.-.regrandtowhichwecome;thattheveryairisablazewithnobleideasandgreatdeeds;thattheheartoftheuniverseisthrobbingwiththeenthusiasmofhumanity;thatthereisdanger,too,andwemustfaceit,andbearourshareifwearegoingouttoseekourfortunesintheworldoflabor.Itistheageofcyclonesanddynamiteandstrikes,andtheheavyblowsfallrightandleft,regardlessofthetearsofwomen,andthecriesofhungrychildren.Yes,yes,wehavebeensentdailyduringourbusinesscoursetotheomnipresentnewspaperforinformationoneverysubjectunderthesun,andweknowthereisastirandabustleandahumthatwedonotfullyunderstand.Itsoundstouslikemartialmusicfaraway,wedonotknowthetunemuchlessthewords.Sometimeswethinkitsays:LaborisKing!LaborisKing,forevermore!andthen,weheararumblingresponse:Mightmakesright!Getwhatyoucan!Keepwhatyouget!dependuponitfriends,weshallhaveouropinions,by-and-by,andwiththecourageofourconvictions,wewilltakepartinthestruggle.Shouldn'twonderifwehelpthewomenofthefutureintheirstrikefor"eighthoursaday"and"goodroundpay,"andtherighttodowhattheypleasewithit.'Го-morrowwewillbereadywithhonestprinciplestodohonestworkforhonestmoney,andtrytowinandwearthecrownofanoblewomanhood.But,to-day,letusdreamourbeautifuldreams,andrevelinourfairyvisions,andbegladthatwearealive,andsurroundedbythenearestanddearestfriendsonearth.Dearfriends,webidyouwelcome!"Fortythousandbrotherscouldnotwithalltheirquantityoflove"makeupthesuminamaiden'sheartwhenshebidsherfriendswelcome!TheSpencerianCollegequartette,composedofMessrs.Newman,Phillips,Steele,andSpencer,thepupilsofMrs.H.H.Mills,renderedthe"NutBrownMaiden"andwerewarmlyencored.TheGentlemkns'ValedictorywasdeliveredbyPaulA.Steele,ofthedayclass,sonofRev.A.FloridusSteele.Notintheheavyarmoroftheoldentime,butinthegarmentsofto-day,madeforspeedanduse,mustwebeclothedfortheswiftraceofmodernlife.Inthisvastcountry,manyroadslieopentoayoungmanfromwhichhemaychoosehiswaytoself-support,andtheunyieldingnecessityforgainingalivelihood,bindinguponmostofus,isamp notacloudtomarthememoryofoneperfectyear.Unitednow,andunitedhenceforthinbondsthatcannotbebroken,wewillbetruetothe"religionoffriendship"inourhearts,eventhoughnowwithvoiceandhandwemustsayfarewell.Dearteachers,ifallthegratitudewefeeltowardyoucouldbeexpressedinwordanddeed,whatjoy,andrest,andpeacewouldcrownyourdays.Forallthesuccesseswemayachieveinlifewewillblessyou,Forourfailureswewillblameonlyourselves.Honor,andtruth,andaccuracy,andreliabilityinalltheworkoflifeyouhavetaughtusbypreceptandexample.Weareproudtobeyourgraduatesandtrusttobealwaysworthyofthathighhonor!Withthanksandlovewebidyoufarewell!




I6SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.TheSt.CeciliaQuartetterendered"AnnieLaurie"veryeffectively,andsangaTyroleanmelodyforanencore.VicePrincipalMrs.SaraA.Spencer,withherpleasingaddress,thentalkedtotheladystudents.Mrs.Spencersaidthatwhentherewerenofirestobuild,noclothestobemended,nowindowstobewashed,noceilingstobeswept,nofloorstobescoured;whentheworldwassohappythatitwantednothingbutanewexperience,awoman,sothemythicallegendsrun,openedPandora'sbox,atetheforbiddenfruitofthetree,andintroducedsinandpainandsorrowanddeathtothehumanfamily.Andthisiswhytheheaviestburdensthroughallsucceedingageshavefallenuponwoman.ItiscertainlyfittingthatsheshouldhavedevotedherselfsofaithfullyandpatientlytoleadingthehumanracetoahigherandholierEden.Throughmuchtribulationhasshewrought.Allwholovetheraceshouldrejoicetoseeherburdenslightened,andbroaderandeasieravenuesopenedforherwearyfeet.Thisiswhatwearetryingtodo.Womenwillnotacceptawantthelessforthemselvesorthosedeartothem,buttheyaregladtolearnhowtosupplywantsmoreeasily.Ouryoungwomenoftheclassof'86arenotafraidtoincorporateintopracticalexperiencewhattheyhavelearnedintheBusinessCollege,yettheyretainthegentleness,tenderness,andwomanlyqualitieswhichhavegiventhemaplaceinourhearts.InhisremarkstothegentlemengraduatesProf.SpencersaidthathepresumedtheprofusionofflowersontheoccasionhadsuggestedtoMrs.SpencerthegardenofEden,andthetransactionthereininvolvingtheapple.Hefeltauthorizedtostatetothelargeaudience,gracedbysomanyfairdaughtersofEve,thatthemenhadlongsinceforgiventhemfortheparttheirmothertookinthataffair.Turningtothegraduates,hethankedthemforthewordsofgratitudeandaffectionspokenbytheirrepresentatives,andsaiditwouldbeaheartlessoldpedagogue,indeed,whowouldnotatleastattemptaresponsetosuchkindlyutterances.Hementionedthefactthatmorethan10,000pupilshadattendedtheCollege,andthatthepresentclasswouldincreasethenumberofgraduatesto672.Allthegraduatesofprecedingyearshadbeencordiallyreceivedintothebusycirclesoftheworld'susefulworkers,andthesewouldsoonbeamongthem.Prof.Spencerthensaid:ThepresenceofourdistinguishedfriendfromIndiana,SenatorYoorhees,whoisabouttoawardthediplomastotheClassof'86,remindsmethatoneyearagoatourCommencementExercises,afacefromaboxonourrightshonewithjoyandsympathyandappreciation—thatofourlamentedVice-President,Thos.A.Hendricks,ofIndiana.[Applause]Atthecloseoftheexercises,hesaid:"ThishasbeenthehappiesthourlbarespentsinceIwasaboy."Ihavethehonortointroducehisfriend,andthefriendofeducation,Hon.DanielW.Voorhees,ofIndiana,U.S.Senator.(ReportedontheStenographbyMissRubyDCrowell,oftheStenographicDepartmentofifcîSpencerianBusinessCollege.)Hon.DanielW.Voorhees,U.S.Senate,ofIndiana,said:LadiesandgentlemenoftheClassofS6:Nowordofminecanenhancetheenjoymentofanoccasionlikethis.Iammoreinstructedbywhatisheretranspiringthancapablerimpartinginstruction.Tothoseofus,wearejourneyingintheafternoonoflifesuch:freshmorningsceneasthis,isfragrantwithinfinitepleasure.Thememoryofsuchscenesthroughwhichwe,ourselves,havepassedisw.vividinourminds,andthesweetthoughtsin¿wordsutteredbythosestandinguponthethresholdofmanhoodandwomanhoodcometous»therichperfumeoftheseflowers1thankyouforthepleasureandhonorofbeinghere.AllusionhasbeenmadetotheStatewhichIhavethehonortorepresent,andtothepresenceofmydistinguishedandeverlamentedfriend,VicePresidentHendricks,whowashereayearago.TheStateofIndianaisindeedworthyofbeingnotedinthecauseofeducation.Withthelargest,permanentschoolfundofan;commonwealthontheglobe,accordingtopoç-ulation,spendingmoremoneypercapitaforeducationthananyotherstateintheUnion,Indianatakesahighaudforemostplacemthegreatcauseofeducation.Incommonschools,normalschools,andcollegesshehasnosuperiorinthis,oranyother,land.Thismaysoundlikeastrongexpressionbutinvestigationwillshowittobeabsolutelytrue.Muchdiscussionhasbeenhadastothestrongestinfluenceintheadvancementoftheworldandinthedevelopmentofmankind.Onehassaidifthepeoplewouldlethimwritetheirsongs,itmatterednotwhomadethelaws.Othershaveheldthatthosewhomakethelawsshapeandmodelthefutureofthepeople.Othersstillholdthatchurchesformthechiefinfluenceinhumanlife.Isayberethattheteachersoftheschoolswillmaleanswerforthefutureofanycountry.Amothersinfluenceisundying.Itgoesfromthecradletothegrave,buttherecomesatimewhentheideaswhichwillgovernthelivesanddestiniesofmenandwomenmustbeinstilledinastrongerandmoreeffectivewaythancanbedoneatthekneeofthemother.Thencommencesthegreatworkoftheteacher,whotakestheyoungmind,formsandfashionsitsthoughts,guidesanddirectsitsaspirations.Teachersarereallythecreatorsofgovernmentandofsocialorder.




SPENCERIANBUSINESSCOLLEGE.«7SincethedayswhenPlatotaughtinacademicgrovesandSocratestaughttheGrecianyouth,theschoolteacherabroadinthelandhasbeenthegreatpowerintheprogressoftheworld.I,therefore,ladiesandgentlemen,takepleasureinbeingpresenttocongratulatetheteachersofthisgreatpracticalschoolupontheirgreatpracticalsuccess,thegoodtheyhavedone,andthegoodtheyarestilldoing.Theirinfluence,andwhattheyhavedonemaynotmakeaclamorintheworld;itmaymakenonoiseforthetimebeing,maynotbeattendedbybandsofmusic,butfromtheirworkgoesstillforthforeverandforevermore,thevitalinfluenceswhichgovernhome,andneighborhoods,societyandatlastgovernmentitself.Theyouthofthiscountryhalt,asitwere,beforeenteringuponthegreatbattleoflife.Theygointoschool,asintoadrilledcamp,andtheretheyareequippedwithbetterarmsthanasoldiereverbore.Inancienttimesthewarriortookhisshield,hisbuckler,hisswordandhisspear,andwastrainedtotheiruse.Thestudentofcivilization,ofChristianeducationreceivesotherandhigherandstrongerweaponsthanallthese.Heistaughttowieldafirmerbuckler,andastoutershieldtowardoffdangerthananyotherevermouldedorlinkedtogether.Heistaughttohandleweaponsinaggressivecombatwitherrorandvice,ofahigherandpurerkind,makingmorelastingimpression,andformoreexaltedpurposesthananyeverconceivedinthecauseofwar.Thesoldiergoesforthequipped,andalsothestudent,onetobattleperhapsforthehomesandlibertyofhiscountry,andtheothertobattlefortheelevationofthemindandsoul,andforthepeaceandhappinessofthehumanracehereandhereafter.TotheseyoungpeoplehereIhavebutafewwordstosay,fortheyhavespokento-daythemselves,andtoeachother,wordsofhighestmoraltone,andofsweetestloveandtemper,andhaveborneinuponourheartsmusicsweeterthantheirsongs.Icongratulateyouuponthisfirststepyouhavetaken.Icongratulateyouthatyouhavereachedthepositionwhereyoustandandbutfewwordsfrommewillbenecessary.Thefirstgreatlessonoflife,youngladiesandyounggentlemen,isthevalueoftime.Neverforgetthis.Asyougrowolderyou,maynever,perhaps,lookuponmyfaceagain.Rememberthatonetime,onamomentousday,thedayyouwilllookbacktoaslongasyoulivewithpleasure,withasenseoftriumph,rememberthatagentlemanstoodbeforeyouandsaid,thatthegreatestlessonoflifewasthevalueoftime.Youmaywasteitinthemorningoflife,youmaycontinuetodoso,butthetimewillcomewhenyouwillfeelthatitismoreprecioustoyouthandiamondsthatarefoundinthefieldsofSouthAfrica.Youwillputoffuntilto-morrow,sayyouwilldoavitalthingfurtheron,butatlastyouwillsuddenlywakeuptothefactthatyouhavenotmuchmoretimeleft.Timeisthatofwhichlifeismade.Itislifeitself.Knowthenthatasyouwasteit,itislikeaburningcandle:itcannotberenewedagain.Itislitbutonce.Itburnsdownandisgoneforever.ThenIwouldsaytoyou,onthisday,onthethresholdofyourmaturelives,makethislessononenevertogofromyourmemory.Treasureitup.Putittogooduse,andyouwillbeamazedatyourownsuccess.Takecareofthemoments,andthedays,weeksandyearswilltakecareofthemselves,andyouwillbesurprisedatthemagnitudeofyourownlearning,andyourachievementsinthepracticalaffairsoftheworld.Betruetoyourselves.Tampernotwithyourconsciences.Therearequicksandsinwhosedepthsthemostbrillianthavegonedownwithlossofsoulandbody.Beuponyourguardagainstthem,andrememberthatnothinginthelongrunpayssowellastotaketherightsideonallsubjects.Itpaysinthisworld,andtheworldtocome.Withtheseremarks,Iwilladdressmyselftothetask,thepleasingtaskofhandingtoyouthoseevidencesofyourindustry,yourlearning,andyourqualifications,whichtheprincipalsofthisexcellentinstitutionhaveawarded,andpreparedforyou.Hethenpresentedthefollowinggraduateswithdiplomas:AliceV.Anderson,MargaretW.Anderson,JuliaA.Bogue,BerthaL.DeGraffe,KateD.Houck,MaryK.Hubble,ClaraR.A.Nelson,NancyMayNesbit,AugustaM.Pettigrew,MabelA.Robinson,RosaM.Schwartz,MargaretB.Sexton,HarrietF.Smith,MargaretT.Sullivan,AugustaC.VVil-lege,FrankB.Bigelow,JuliusS.Buynitzky,JohnBreck,LincolnE.Buck,GeorgeW.Cook,SamuelB.Davis,CharlesL.Davison,WilliamD.Deloe,DanielA.Duffy,ArchibaldEdmomton,CharlesF.Ely,JohnAdrianEpping,EberhardFordan,GeorgeС.French,HoratioG.Gibson,Jr.;JosephD.Healy,Juliuslose,AlbertJohns,WilliamJ.Jones,LouisP.Keyser,Lo GLENWOODCEMETERY.Thisbeautiful"CityoftheDead"islocatedonLincolnAvenue,abouthalfamilefromBoundaryStreet,situatedonthehighgroundoverlookingtheCityof"Washington,andonthelinewithNorthCapitolStreet.Itcontainsaboutninetyacres,andislaidoutontheplanofthecelebratedGreenwoodCemeteryofNewYork.TheremainsofmanyofWashington'smostnotedcitizensarehereinterred.GlenwoodwasincorporatedJuly27,1854,whichactofIncorporationwasamendedFebruary27,1877,committingthecontrolanddirectionoftheCemeterytoaBoardofFiveTrustees,tobeelectedannuallybythelotowners.ThepresentBoardconsistsof:WILLIAMLORD,LEWISCLEPHANE,H.O.TOWLES,THOMASJ.FISHER,andDr.D.McFARLAN.WILLIAMLORD,Pres't.H.O.TOWLES,Treas.LEWISCLEPHANE,Secretary.ALEXANDERMcKERICHAR,Superintendent.TheSuperintendent1«alwaysattheCemetery,andwillcheerfullyfarиtalkallotherInformation.TheCemeteryIsConnectedbyTelephone.ROCKCREEKCEMETERY.ContiguoustoandimmediatelynorthoftheSoldiers'Homeliesthe"Globe,"ofonehundredacres,withthevenerableedificethereonknownas"RockCreekChurch,"or,moreproperly,St.Paul'sChurch,RockCreekParish.Thelandwasthegift,inColonialtimes,ofJohnBradford,Esq,tobeheldinperpetuityforchurchpurposes.Aportionofthegroundlyingjustabovethechurchhaslongbeenusedforinterment,thisbeingtheoldestchurchandburialgroundwithintheDistrict,havingbeensousedsince1719.Appreciatingthesacredassociationsthatsurroundtheplaceanditsnaturalbeautyandadvantages,theVestrycausedasurveyofaboutone-halfofthe"Globe"tobemade,andBetthesameasideforcemeterypurposes.Itisinmostpartshadedbyforesttreesofnaturalgrowthandgreatage.Theoldchurchwithitsregularservice—theretiredandquietcharacterofthesurroundings—securefromthefutureencroachmentsofthecitymustcommendthiscemeterytoall.OTFIOBB.SiRev.I.A.BUCK,ЛJOHÑCmÍllIrTER'УCemeteryCommittee.В.FRITTENHOUSE,)J.В.WILTBERGER.M.L.MOÜDY,SecretaryandTreasurer.Superintendent.TheSuperintendentlaalway.attheCemetery,andwillcheerfullyfurnishallotherInformation.TheCemeteryImconnectedhyTelephone.FLOWERSCUTORPOTTEDFURNISHEDFROMTHEGREENHOUSES.59(929)

Congress,Capitolbuilding,commencedin1800,destroyedbyfirein1814,afterwardsreplenishedbythepurchasebyCongressofthelibraryofEx-PresidentJefferson,embracingabout7,000volumes,In185135,000volumesweredestroyedbyfire;rebuiltin1852,when$75,000wereappropriatedtoreplenishthecollection.ThelibraryisrecruitedbyregularappropriationsmadebyCongress,whichaverageabout$11,000perannum;alsobyadditionsreceivedbycopyright,byexchanges,andfromtheSmithsonianInstitution.ThelibraryoftheSmithsonianInstitutionhasbeendeposited




946LIBRARIES.LITERARYSOCIETIES.IntheLibraryoíCongress,whereitissecureagainstlossbylire;thiscollectionisespeciallyrichinscientificworks,embracingthelargestassemblageofthetransactionsoflearnedsocietieswhichexistsinthecountry.ThelibraryofcopyrightbookswasremovedherefromthePatentOfficein1870,andiscontinuallygrowing,andallcopyrightsissuedintheUnitedStatesarenowrecordedintheofficeofthelibrarianofCongress.Thepresentnumberofvolumesiuthewholelibrary,includinglawbooks,whicharekeptinaseparatelibraryundertheSupremeCourt,isover565,000.TheTonerlibrary,num-beringover25,000volumes,wasaddedin1882,havingbeenpresentedtotheUnitedStatesbytheliberalandpublic-spiriteddonor,DrJosephMToner,ofWashington.ThiscollectionistemporarilystoredinaroomundertherotundaoftheCapitol,andadditionsareannuallymadetoitbyDrToner.TheLibraryofCongressisveryrichinhistory,politicalscience,jurisprudence,andiubooks,pamphletsandperiodicalsofAmericanpublication,orrelatingiuanvwaytoAmerica.Atthesametimethelibraryisuniversalinitsrange,nodepartmentofliteratureorsciencebeingunrepresented.ThepublicareprivilegedtheuseofthebooksInthelibrary,whilemembersofCongressandaboutthirtyofficialmembersofthegovernmentonlycantakeawaybooks.Thelibraryisopendaily(exceptSundays)duringthesessionofCongress,fromУaintothehourofadjournment.InthereceseofCongressitisopenbetween9amand4pm.Librarian,AlnsworthRSpofford,1621MassavnwAssistants,CharlesWHoffman,114Mdavne;LouisSolyom,138ECap;DavidHutche-son,Brooksstation;JamesСStrout,127Enw;JohnSavary,15341nw;WJDockstader,148Ane;PaulNeuhaus,6076thnw;JSPWheeler,311Delavne;GeorgeAMark,609Fnw;ThorvaldSolborg,Anacostia;PLeePhillips,1707Hnw;MSchlosser,921Gnw;SpencerMarsh,221Ase;VernonDor-sey,2025Nnw;WMGrlswold,206Delavne;TJPutnam,Anacostia-JFNWilkinson,»01Esw;DanielMurray,133312thnw;JGMorrison,81113thnw;ACrlsfleld,163329thnw;PСNicholas,1924Nnw;JohnJKey,3327PnwCarrollInstituteLibrary,602Fnw;numberofvolumes3,000.PeabodyLibrary,3233Оnw;librarian,FrankÜJohns.YoungMen'sChristianAssociation,1409NYavnw,1,200volumes,fre
